When I try to suppress warning output from ConvertTo-Json, and use -WarningAction Stop, I still get the Warning message sent to the Warning stream.
I would expect the Warning message to be suppressed and contained in the generated exception instead.
-WarningAction SilentlyContinue works as expected.

## Steps to reproduce

```powershell
$x = (Get-ChildItem | ConvertTo-Json -Depth 2 -WarningAction Stop)
```

## Expected behavior

Throws an exception and outputs the text
```none
"ConvertTo-Json: The running command stopped because the preference variable "WarningPreference" or common parameter is set to Stop: Resulting JSON is truncated as serialization has exceeded the set depth of 2."
```

## Actual behavior

Throws an exception and outputs the text
```none
WARNING: Resulting JSON is truncated as serialization has exceeded the set depth of 2.
ConvertTo-Json: The running command stopped because the preference variable "WarningPreference" or common parameter is set to Stop: Resulting JSON is truncated as serialization has exceeded the set depth of 2.
```

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
You can try the following ``` function test { [cmdletbinding()] Param() Write-Warning "warning" Write-error "error" Write-host "Host" } ``` ` test -ErrorAction stop ` Prints the error message and stops ` test -WarningAction Stop` Prints the warning message and stops. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.management.automation.actionpreference?view=powershellsdk-7.0.0 should say explicitly that the messages are printed. This is by design, stopping because of an error / warning condition - but doing so silently, meaning the user doesn't know what has happened would generally be considered to be a bad thing.
ActionPreference Enum (System.Management.Automation)
Defines the Action Preference options. These options determine what will happen when a particular type of event occurs. For example, setting shell variable ErrorActionPreference to "Stop" will cause the command to stop when an otherwise non-terminating error occurs.

comments.author: donlassini
comments.body:
"This is by design, stopping because of an error / warning condition - but doing so silently, meaning the user doesn't know what has happened would generally be considered to be a bad thing."

Isn't that what the ErrorVariable and WarningVariable parameters are for? I don't think you'd want to use "-warningaction stop" if you're in an interactive prompt, hence there's no need to display that to the user.
If the user is smart enough to ask for a full stop, the user should also be smart enough to use these options.

I resolved my issue by redirecting the warning stream to $null

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
@donlassini  

Well there are a couple of assumptions, one is that you would specify and check warning variable every time you used -warningAction stop in the script and report the issue as needed.  The second is not using -stop interactively - it's not common but it is used. 
Redirecting the message is the right way to go. 

However I did find one thing checking on this 
with that test function 
`try {test } catch {"boo"}`    
Outputs everything     
`try {test -ErrorAction Stop} catch {"boo"}`    
Outputs "boo" _instead of_ the error message,
`try {test -WarningAction Stop} catch {"boo"}`
Outputs "boo" _in addition to_ the warning message - and the error in the catch block is not the warning message but the " The running command stopped because the preference variable "WarningPreference" or common parameter is set to Stop: warning"

title: ConvertTo-Json still outputs a warning when WarningAction is set to 'Stop'
